cards.name: Ransack
cards.text: Look at the top five cards of target player's library. Put any number of them on the bottom of that library in any order and the rest on top of the library in any order.
cards.originalText: Look at the top five cards of target player's library. Put any number of those cards on the bottom of that library in any order and the rest on top of the library in any order.

cards.name: Rebound
cards.text: Change the target of target spell that targets only a player. The new target must be a player.
cards.flavor: Insult, like an arrow, is beyond control once loosed.

rulings.text: You can't use this on a spell unless the target spell is an Aura or uses the word "target" in its text. If it isn't an Aura and the word "target" is not there, then the spell does not target a player at all—it just affects a player without targeting them.

cards.originalText: Target spell, which targets only a single player, targets another player of your choice instead.

cards.name: Reins of Power
cards.text: Untap all creatures you control and all creatures target opponent controls. You and that opponent each gain control of all creatures the other controls until end of turn. Those creatures gain haste until end of turn.

rulings.text: It is perfectly legal for either or both players to have zero creatures. They give control of all their zero creatures as instructed.
You only untap creatures controlled by you and the targeted opponent, not all creatures.

cards.originalText: You and target opponent each untap and gain control of all creatures the other controls until end of turn. Those creatures are unaffected by summoning sickness this turn.

cards.name: Revenant
cards.text:
Flying
Revenant's power and toughness are each equal to the number of creature cards in your graveyard.
cards.flavor:
"Not again."
—Hans

rulings.text: The ability that defines Revenant's power and toughness applies in all zones, not just the battlefield. If Revenant is in your graveyard, its ability will count itself.

cards.originalText:
Flying
Revenant has power and toughness each equal to the number of creature cards in your graveyard.

cards.name: Rolling Stones
cards.text: Wall creatures can attack as though they didn't have defender.
cards.flavor: Walls collapse and kill people all the time. Some are just more aggressive about it.
cards.originalText: Walls can attack as though they were not Walls.

cards.name: Ruination
cards.text: Destroy all nonbasic lands.
cards.flavor:
"We have built a wall upon sand. The wall will vanish. The sand will remain."
—Oracle en-Vec
cards.originalText: Destroy all nonbasic lands.

cards.name: Sacred Ground
cards.text: Whenever a spell or ability an opponent controls causes a land to be put into your graveyard from the battlefield, return that card to the battlefield.
cards.flavor:
"That which knows itself cannot be shaped to another's will."
—Oracle en-Vec
cards.originalText: Whenever an effect controlled by any opponent puts a land into your graveyard from play, put that land into play.

cards.name: Samite Blessing
cards.text:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature has "{T}: The next time a source of your choice would deal damage to target creature this turn, prevent that damage."
cards.flavor:
Knit bone, darn flesh,
Stitch skin, weave breath.
—Samite healing ritual
cards.originalText: Enchanted creature gains "{T}: Prevent all damage to any creature from any one source." (Treat further damage from that source normally.)

cards.name: Carnassid
cards.text:
Trample
{1}{G}: Regenerate Carnassid.
cards.flavor: The hunter would never forget the time or place where he first met the carnassid, for they buried him there.
cards.originalText:
Trample
{1}{G}: Regenerate Carnassid.

cards.name: Seething Anger
cards.text:
Buyback {3} (You may pay an additional {3} as you cast this spell. If you do, put this card into your hand as it resolves.)
Target creature gets +3/+0 until end of turn.
cards.originalText:
Buyback {3} (You may pay an additional {3} when you play this spell. If you do, put it into your hand instead of your graveyard as part of the spell's effect.)
Target creature gets +3/+0 until end of turn.

cards.name: Serpent Warrior
cards.text: When Serpent Warrior enters the battlefield, you lose 3 life.
cards.flavor: A hiss before dying.

rulings.text: You can cast this if you have less than 3 life, since the life is lost as an effect and not a payment.

cards.originalText: When Serpent Warrior comes into play, lose 3 life.

cards.name: Shaman en-Kor
cards.text:
{0}: The next 1 damage that would be dealt to Shaman en-Kor this turn is dealt to target creature you control instead.
{1}{W}: The next time a source of your choice would deal damage to target creature this turn, that damage is dealt to Shaman en-Kor instead.

rulings.text: The ability of this card does not do anything to stop Trample damage from being assigned to the defending player.
It can redirect damage to itself.
It is possible to redirect more damage to a creature than that creature's toughness.
You can use this ability as much as you want prior to damage being dealt.
When you redirect combat damage it is still combat damage.

cards.originalText:
{0}: Redirect 1 damage from Shaman en-Kor to a creature you control.
{1}{W}: Redirect to Shaman en-Kor all damage dealt to any one creature from any one source.

cards.name: Shifting Wall
cards.text:
Defender (This creature can't attack.)
Shifting Wall enters the battlefield with X +1/+1 counters on it.
cards.flavor:
"You'd almost think Volrath doesn't want me here."
—Gerrard
cards.originalText:
Shifting Wall counts as a Wall. (Walls cannot attack.)
Shifting Wall comes into play with X +1/+1 counters on it.

cards.name: Sift
cards.text: Draw three cards, then discard a card.
cards.flavor:
"Twice I have let the Legacy slip away. Never again."
—Karn, silver golem
cards.originalText: Draw three cards, then choose and discard a card.

cards.name: Skyshroud Falcon
cards.text: Flying, vigilance
cards.flavor:
The falcon slits the sky to let the light drip through.
—Kor saying

rulings.text: No it is not a Falcon creature type. It is a Bird.

cards.originalText:
Flying
Attacking does not cause Skyshroud Falcon to tap.

cards.name: Skeleton Scavengers
cards.text:
Skeleton Scavengers enters the battlefield with a +1/+1 counter on it.
Pay {1} for each +1/+1 counter on Skeleton Scavengers: Regenerate Skeleton Scavengers. When it regenerates this way, put a +1/+1 counter on it.
cards.originalText:
Skeleton Scavengers comes into play with one +1/+1 counter on it.
Pay {1} for each +1/+1 counter on Skeleton Scavengers: Regenerate Skeleton Scavengers and put a +1/+1 counter on it.

cards.name: Skyshroud Archer
cards.text: {T}: Target creature with flying gets -1/-1 until end of turn.
cards.flavor: In Rath, arrows are guided not by virtue but by necessity.
cards.originalText: {T}: Target creature with flying gets -1/-1 until end of turn.

cards.name: Skyshroud Troopers
cards.text: {T}: Add {G}.
cards.flavor:
"We were not made for war. Like flowstone, Volrath shaped us to it."
—Eladamri, Lord of Leaves
cards.originalText: {T}: Add {G} to your mana pool. Play this ability as a mana source.

cards.name: Sliver Queen
cards.text: {2}: Create a 1/1 colorless Sliver creature token.
cards.flavor: Her children are ever part of her.
cards.originalText:
Sliver Queen counts as a Sliver.
{2}: Put a Sliver token into play. Treat this token as a 1/1 colorless creature.

cards.name: Smite
cards.text: Destroy target blocked creature.
cards.flavor:
"You've got your childhood wish at last. Now you get to die."
—Gerrard, to Volrath

rulings.text: A "blocked creature" is an attacking creature that has been blocked by a creature this combat, or has become blocked as the result of a spell or ability this combat. Unless the attacking creature leaves combat, it continues to be a blocked creature through the end of combat step, even if the creature or creatures that blocked it are no longer on the battlefield or have otherwise left combat by then.

cards.originalText: Destroy target blocked creature.

cards.name: Soltari Champion
cards.text:
Shadow (This creature can block or be blocked by only creatures with shadow.)
Whenever Soltari Champion attacks, other creatures you control get +1/+1 until end of turn.
cards.originalText:
Shadow (This creature can block or be blocked by only creatures with shadow.)
If Soltari Champion attacks, all other creatures you control get +1/+1 until end of turn.

cards.name: Spirit en-Kor
cards.text:
Flying
{0}: The next 1 damage that would be dealt to Spirit en-Kor this turn is dealt to target creature you control instead.
cards.flavor:
Death free throat from thirst, mouth from speech, feet from earth.
—Kor requiem

rulings.text: The ability of this card does not do anything to stop Trample damage from being assigned to the defending player.
It can redirect damage to itself.
It is possible to redirect more damage to a creature than that creature's toughness.
You can use this ability as much as you want prior to damage being dealt.
When you redirect combat damage it is still combat damage.

cards.originalText:
Flying
{0}: Redirect 1 damage from Spirit en-Kor to a creature you control.

cards.name: Spike Breeder
cards.text:
Spike Breeder enters the battlefield with three +1/+1 counters on it.
{2}, Remove a +1/+1 counter from Spike Breeder: Put a +1/+1 counter on target creature.
{2}, Remove a +1/+1 counter from Spike Breeder: Create a 1/1 green Spike creature token.
cards.originalText:
Spike Breeder comes into play with three +1/+1 counters on it.
{2}, Remove a +1/+1 counter from Spike Breeder: Put a +1/+1 counter on target creature.
{2}, Remove a +1/+1 counter from Spike Breeder: Put a Spike token into play. Treat this token as a 1/1 green creature.

cards.name: Spike Colony
cards.text:
Spike Colony enters the battlefield with four +1/+1 counters on it.
{2}, Remove a +1/+1 counter from Spike Colony: Put a +1/+1 counter on target creature.
cards.originalText:
Spike Colony comes into play with four +1/+1 counters on it.
{2}, Remove a +1/+1 counter from Spike Colony: Put a +1/+1 counter on target creature.

cards.name: Spike Feeder
cards.text:
Spike Feeder enters the battlefield with two +1/+1 counters on it.
{2}, Remove a +1/+1 counter from Spike Feeder: Put a +1/+1 counter on target creature.
Remove a +1/+1 counter from Spike Feeder: You gain 2 life.
cards.originalText:
Spike Feeder comes into play with two +1/+1 counters on it.
{2}, Remove a +1/+1 counter from Spike Feeder: Put a +1/+1 counter on target creature.
Remove a +1/+1 counter from Spike Feeder: Gain 2 life.

cards.name: Spike Soldier
cards.text:
Spike Soldier enters the battlefield with three +1/+1 counters on it.
{2}, Remove a +1/+1 counter from Spike Soldier: Put a +1/+1 counter on target creature.
Remove a +1/+1 counter from Spike Soldier: Spike Soldier gets +2/+2 until end of turn.
cards.originalText:
Spike Soldier comes into play with three +1/+1 counters on it.
{2}, Remove a +1/+1 counter from Spike Soldier: Put a +1/+1 counter on target creature.
Remove a +1/+1 counter from Spike Soldier: Spike Soldier gets +2/+2 until end of turn.

cards.name: Spike Worker
cards.text:
Spike Worker enters the battlefield with two +1/+1 counters on it.
{2}, Remove a +1/+1 counter from Spike Worker: Put a +1/+1 counter on target creature.
cards.originalText:
Spike Worker comes into play with two +1/+1 counters on it.
{2}, Remove a +1/+1 counter from Spike Worker: Put a +1/+1 counter on target creature.

cards.name: Spindrift Drake
cards.text:
Flying
At the beginning of your upkeep, sacrifice Spindrift Drake unless you pay {U}.
cards.flavor: Sea brine for blood, washing foam for laughter.
cards.originalText:
Flying
During your upkeep, pay {U} or sacrifice Spindrift Drake.

cards.name: Spined Wurm
cards.flavor:
"As it moved, the wurm's spines gathered up bits of flowstone, which took the shapes of dead villagers' heads. Each head spoke a single sound, but if taken together, they said, 'Alas for the living.'"
—Dal myth of the wurm

cards.name: Spitting Hydra
cards.text:
Spitting Hydra enters the battlefield with four +1/+1 counters on it.
{1}{R}, Remove a +1/+1 counter from Spitting Hydra: Spitting Hydra deals 1 damage to target creature.
cards.originalText:
Spitting Hydra comes into play with four +1/+1 counters on it.
{1}{R}, Remove a +1/+1 counter from Spitting Hydra: Spitting Hydra deals 1 damage to target creature.

cards.name: Stronghold Assassin
cards.text: {T}, Sacrifice a creature: Destroy target nonblack creature.
cards.flavor: The assassin sees only throats and hears only heartbeats.
cards.originalText: {T}, Sacrifice a creature: Destroy target nonblack creature.

cards.name: Stronghold Taskmaster
cards.text: Other black creatures get -1/-1.
cards.flavor:
"With the completion of each joyous task, we are closer to Yawgmoth's divine vision."
—Stronghold architect, journal
cards.originalText: All other black creatures get -1/-1.

cards.name: Sword of the Chosen
cards.text: {T}: Target legendary creature gets +2/+2 until end of turn.
cards.flavor: One shard of Selenia yet remained.
cards.originalText: {T}: Target legend gets +2/+2 until end of turn.

cards.name: Temper
cards.text: Prevent the next X damage that would be dealt to target creature this turn. For each 1 damage prevented this way, put a +1/+1 counter on that creature.
cards.flavor:
"I don't need a plan, just a goal. The rest will follow on its own."
—Gerrard

rulings.text: You can make X be larger than the amount of damage, but you only get one counter for each actual point of damage prevented.
The +1/+1 counters do show up at the same time as any unprevented damage, which means they are there before you check for lethal damage.

cards.originalText: Prevent up to X damage to target creature. For each 1 damage prevented in this way, put a +1/+1 counter on that creature.

cards.name: Tempting Licid
cards.text:
{G}, {T}: Tempting Licid loses this ability and becomes an Aura enchantment with enchant creature. Attach it to target creature. You may pay {G} to end this effect.
All creatures able to block enchanted creature do so.

rulings.text: Paying the cost to end the effect is a special action and can't be responded to.

If a spell that can target enchantments but not creatures (such as Clear) is cast targeting the Licid after it has become an enchantment, but the Licid's controller pays the cost, the Licid will no longer be an enchantment. This will result in the spell failing to resolve for having no legal targets.

cards.originalText: {G}, {T}: Tempting Licid loses ability and becomes a creature enchantment that reads "All creatures able to block enchanted creature do so" instead of a creature. Move Tempting Licid onto target creature. You may pay {G} to end this effect.

cards.name: Thalakos Deceiver
cards.text:
Shadow (This creature can block or be blocked by only creatures with shadow.)
Whenever Thalakos Deceiver attacks and isn't blocked, you may sacrifice it. If you do, gain control of target creature. (This effect lasts indefinitely.)

rulings.text: An ability that triggers when something "attacks and isn't blocked" triggers in the declare blockers step after blockers are declared if (1) that creature is attacking and (2) no creatures are declared to block it. It will trigger even if that creature was put onto the battlefield attacking rather than having been declared as an attacker in the declare attackers step.

cards.originalText:
Shadow (This creature can block or be blocked by only creatures with shadow.)
Sacrifice Thalakos Deceiver: Gain control of target creature permanently. Use this ability only if Thalakos Deceiver is attacking and unblocked.

cards.name: Tidal Surge
cards.text: Tap up to three target creatures without flying.
cards.flavor:
"It is nature that gives us our boundaries and nature that enforces them."
—Eladamri, Lord of Leaves
cards.originalText: Tap up to three target creatures without flying.

cards.name: Tidal Warrior
cards.text: {T}: Target land becomes an Island until end of turn.
cards.flavor: The tide of battle favors those who can swim.
cards.originalText: {T}: Target land is an island until end of turn.

cards.name: Torment
cards.text:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature gets -3/-0.
cards.flavor:
"Volrath has killed me. All that remains of me is the scar!"
—Tahngarth
cards.originalText: Enchanted creature gets -3/-0.

cards.name: Venerable Monk
cards.text: When Venerable Monk enters the battlefield, you gain 2 life.
cards.flavor: Age wears the flesh but galvanizes the soul.
cards.originalText: When Venerable Monk comes into play, gain 2 life.

cards.name: Verdant Touch
cards.text:
Buyback {3} (You may pay an additional {3} as you cast this spell. If you do, put this card into your hand as it resolves.)
Target land becomes a 2/2 creature that's still a land. (This effect lasts indefinitely.)

rulings.text: The land is still a land and retains all its abilities, plus any other characteristics.

A noncreature permanent that turns into a creature can attack, and its {T} abilities can be activated, only if its controller has continuously controlled that permanent since the beginning of their most recent turn. It doesn't matter how long the permanent has been a creature.

cards.originalText:
Buyback {3} (You may pay an additional {3} when you play this spell. If you do, put it into your hand instead of your graveyard as part of the spell's effect.)
Target land becomes a 2/2 creature permanently. (This creature still counts as a land.)

cards.name: Volrath's Gardens
cards.text: {2}, Tap an untapped creature you control: You gain 2 life. Activate this ability only any time you could cast a sorcery.
cards.flavor: "Watch yourself," warned Starke. "These plants aren't nice when they're hungry."
cards.originalText: {2}, Tap a creature you control: Gain 2 life. Play this ability as a sorcery.

cards.name: Volrath's Laboratory
cards.text:
As Volrath's Laboratory enters the battlefield, choose a color and a creature type.
{5}, {T}: Create a 2/2 creature token of the chosen color and type.

rulings.text: The token has the same name as the creature type.
The token does not have any built-in abilities. For example, choosing creature type Bird does not give the token Flying.

cards.originalText:
When you play Volrath's Laboratory, choose a color and a creature type.
{5}, {T}: Put a token creature into play. Treat this token as a 2/2 creature of the chosen color and creature type.

cards.name: Volrath's Shapeshifter
cards.text:
As long as the top card of your graveyard is a creature card, Volrath's Shapeshifter has the full text of that card and has the text "{2}: Discard a card." (Volrath's Shapeshifter has that card's name, mana cost, color, types, abilities, power, and toughness.)
{2}: Discard a card.

rulings.text: If the top card in the graveyard has any other undefined characteristics, then those characteristics are not acquired and the shapeshifter uses the characteristic from its own card.

If the top card in your graveyard is a creature card, this card uses the listed characteristics, including color and any other types. But, this card keeps the granted ability in addition to those from the card being copied.
When it changes forms, any "enters the battlefield" abilities of the card it "copies" do not trigger.
A copy of a Volrath's Shapeshifter will have the shapeshifting ability.

If the top card in your graveyard isn't a creature card (meaning a card with the type Creature, which may or may not have other types such as Artifact or Enchantment), then it's just a 0/1 blue creature. Older cards of type Summon are also Creature cards.
The ability that sets its characteristics is a text-changing effect.

cards.originalText:
As long as the top card of your graveyard is a creature card, Volrath's Shapeshifter is a copy of that card, except that Volrath's Shapeshifter retains its abilities.
{2}: Choose and discard a card.

cards.name: Volrath's Stronghold
cards.text:
{T}: Add {C}.
{1}{B}, {T}: Put target creature card from your graveyard on top of your library.
cards.flavor: The seed of a world's evil.
cards.originalText:
{T}: Add one colorless mana to your mana pool.
{1}{B}, {T}: Put target creature card from your graveyard on top of your library.

cards.name: Walking Dream
cards.text:
Walking Dream can't be blocked.
Walking Dream doesn't untap during your untap step if an opponent controls two or more creatures.
cards.flavor: Dreams, by definition, live shorter lives than those who dream them.
cards.originalText:
Walking Dream is unblockable.
Walking Dream does not untap during your untap phase if any opponent controls two or more creatures.

cards.name: Wall of Blossoms
cards.text:
Defender
When Wall of Blossoms enters the battlefield, draw a card.
cards.flavor: Each flower identical, every leaf and petal disturbingly exact.
cards.originalText:
(Walls cannot attack.)
When Wall of Blossoms comes into play, draw a card.

cards.name: Wall of Essence
cards.text:
Defender (This creature can't attack.)
Whenever Wall of Essence is dealt combat damage, you gain that much life.
cards.flavor:
The ceiling and the floor fell in love, but only the wall knew.
—Dal saying

rulings.text: Wall of Essence's triggered ability will trigger even if it's dealt lethal damage. For example, if it's dealt 7 combat damage, its ability will trigger and you'll gain 7 life.

cards.originalText:
(Walls cannot attack.)
For each 1 combat damage dealt to Wall of Essence, gain 1 life.

cards.name: Wall of Razors
cards.text:
Defender (This creature can't attack.)
First strike
cards.flavor:
"In this blessed structure let the very walls baptize themselves in the blood of intruders."
—Stronghold architect, journal
cards.originalText:
(Walls cannot attack.)
First strike

cards.name: Wall of Souls
cards.text:
Defender (This creature can't attack.)
Whenever Wall of Souls is dealt combat damage, it deals that much damage to target opponent or planeswalker.
cards.flavor:
"It is the nature of evil to turn you against yourself."
—Starke

rulings.text: Redirected damage is still combat damage, so it will trigger on combat damage that is redirected to it.

cards.originalText:
(Walls cannot attack.)
Whenever Wall of Souls is dealt combat damage, it deals an equal amount of damage to target opponent.

cards.name: Wall of Tears
cards.text:
Defender (This creature can't attack.)
Whenever Wall of Tears blocks a creature, return that creature to its owner's hand at end of combat.
cards.flavor:
"Many have been lost to pity."
—Karn, silver golem
cards.originalText:
(Walls cannot attack.)
If Wall of Tears blocks any creatures, return each of those creatures to owner's hand at end of combat.

cards.name: Warrior Angel
cards.text:
Flying
Whenever Warrior Angel deals damage, you gain that much life.
cards.flavor: She represents not hope, but hope's desperate fury.
cards.originalText:
Flying
For each 1 damage Warrior Angel deals, gain 1 life.

cards.name: Warrior en-Kor
cards.text: {0}: The next 1 damage that would be dealt to Warrior en-Kor this turn is dealt to target creature you control instead.
cards.flavor: Only a matter as vital as destroying Volrath could bring together the reclusive Kor people.

rulings.text: The ability of this card does not do anything to stop Trample damage from being assigned to the defending player.
It can redirect damage to itself.
It is possible to redirect more damage to a creature than that creature's toughness.
You can use this ability as much as you want prior to damage being dealt.
When you redirect combat damage it is still combat damage.

cards.originalText: {0}: Redirect 1 damage from Warrior en-Kor to a creature you control.

cards.name: Youthful Knight
cards.text: First strike
cards.flavor:
"Let no child be without a sword. We will all fight, for if we fail, we will certainly all die."
—Oracle en-Vec
cards.originalText: First strike

cards.name: Abuna Acolyte
cards.text:
{T}: Prevent the next 1 damage that would be dealt to any target this turn.
{T}: Prevent the next 2 damage that would be dealt to target artifact creature this turn.
cards.flavor: "You can break nothing I cannot mend."
cards.originalText:
{T}: Prevent the next 1 damage that would be dealt to target creature or player this turn.
{T}: Prevent the next 2 damage that would be dealt to target artifact creature this turn.

cards.name: Arrest
cards.text:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature can't attack or block, and its activated abilities can't be activated.
cards.flavor: Bladehold houses a rogues' gallery filled with the living "statues" of the worst enemies of the Auriok.

rulings.text: Activated abilities contain a colon. They're generally written "[Cost]: [Effect]." Some keywords are activated abilities and will have colons in their reminder text.

cards.originalText:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature can't attack or block, and its activated abilities can't be activated.

cards.name: Auriok Edgewright
cards.text: Metalcraft — Auriok Edgewright has double strike as long as you control three or more artifacts.
cards.flavor: Auriok soldiers craft their own weapons, forging a connection to the steel with each blow of the hammer.

rulings.text: If Auriok Edgewright has double strike as the combat damage step begins, there will be a second combat damage step. As that second combat damage step begins, if Auriok Edgewright no longer has double strike (perhaps because an artifact creature you controlled was destroyed), Auriok Edgewright will not assign combat damage a second time.

cards.originalText: Metalcraft — Auriok Edgewright has double strike as long as you control three or more artifacts.

cards.name: Auriok Sunchaser
cards.text: Metalcraft — As long as you control three or more artifacts, Auriok Sunchaser gets +2/+2 and has flying.
cards.flavor:
"Grant me loft. Grant me light. Grant me the accuracy I need to kill all who threaten Bladehold."
—Prayer to the Whitesun

rulings.text: For the purposes of blocking (either because Auriok Sunchaser is attacking or because a creature with flying is attacking Auriok Sunchaser's controller), whether Auriok Sunchaser has flying is checked only as the declare blockers step begins.
If Auriok Sunchaser blocks a creature with flying, causing it to lose flying (by destroying an artifact its controller controls, for example) won't change that.

foreignNames.name: オーリオックの太陽追い

cards.originalText: Metalcraft — As long as you control three or more artifacts, Auriok Sunchaser gets +2/+2 and has flying.

cards.name: Dispense Justice
cards.text:
Target player sacrifices an attacking creature.
Metalcraft — That player sacrifices two attacking creatures instead if you control three or more artifacts.
cards.flavor: The Accorders never strike first, but they always strike back.

rulings.text: The targeted player chooses which attacking creature(s) to sacrifice as Dispense Justice resolves.

cards.originalText:
Target player sacrifices an attacking creature.
Metalcraft — That player sacrifices two attacking creatures instead if you control three or more artifacts.

cards.name: Elspeth Tirel
cards.text:
+2: You gain 1 life for each creature you control.
−2: Create three 1/1 white Soldier creature tokens.
−5: Destroy all other permanents except for lands and tokens.

rulings.text: As Elspeth Tirel's last ability resolves, each permanent that isn't a token, a land, or Elspeth Tirel herself is destroyed.

foreignNames.name: エルズペス・ティレル

cards.originalText:
+2: You gain 1 life for each creature you control.
-2: Put three 1/1 white Soldier creature tokens onto the battlefield.
-5: Destroy all other permanents except
for lands and tokens.

cards.name: Fulgent Distraction
cards.text: Choose two target creatures. Tap those creatures, then unattach all Equipment from them.
cards.flavor:
"Channeling the white-hot power of all five suns creates a pretty good diversion."
—Yavash of the Accorders

rulings.text: You must target two creatures as you cast Fulgent Distraction. If you can't (because there's just one creature on the battlefield, perhaps), you can't cast the spell.
Fulgent Distraction can target tapped and/or unequipped creatures.

If one of the targeted creatures is an illegal target by the time Fulgent Distraction resolves, that creature won't become tapped and no Equipment will be unattached from it. The other creature will still be affected. If both of the targeted creatures are illegal targets by the time Fulgent Distraction resolves, the spell doesn't resolve.

cards.originalText: Choose two target creatures. Tap those creatures, then unattach all Equipment from them.

cards.name: Ghalma's Warden
cards.text: Metalcraft — Ghalma's Warden gets +2/+2 as long as you control three or more artifacts.
cards.flavor: A special unit guards the loxodon artificer known as Ghalma the Shaper. They are armed and armored in her finest works of silver and steel.
cards.originalText: Metalcraft — Ghalma's Warden gets +2/+2 as long as you control three or more artifacts.

cards.name: Glimmerpoint Stag
cards.text:
Vigilance
When Glimmerpoint Stag enters the battlefield, exile another target permanent. Return that card to the battlefield under its owner's control at the beginning of the next end step.

rulings.text: If a token is exiled this way, it ceases to exist and won't return to the battlefield.
The exiled card will return to the battlefield at the beginning of the next end step even if Glimmerpoint Stag is no longer on the battlefield at that time.

If the exiled card is an Aura, that card's owner chooses what it will enchant as it comes back onto the battlefield. An Aura put onto the battlefield this way doesn't target anything (so it could be attached to a permanent with shroud, for example), but the Aura's enchant ability restricts what it can be attached to. If the Aura can't legally be attached to anything, it remains exiled.
If Glimmerpoint Stag somehow enters the battlefield during a turn's end step, the exiled card won't be returned to the battlefield until the beginning of the following turn's end step.

cards.originalText:
Vigilance
When Glimmerpoint Stag enters the battlefield, exile another target permanent. Return that card to the battlefield under its owner's control at the beginning of the next end step.

cards.name: Glint Hawk
cards.text:
Flying
When Glint Hawk enters the battlefield, sacrifice it unless you return an artifact you control to its owner's hand.
cards.flavor: Its eyes burned nearly blind by the Whitesun, it hunts by metallic gleam.

rulings.text: You may choose to sacrifice Glint Hawk as its triggered ability resolves even if you control an artifact.

You choose which artifact to return to its owner's hand as the triggered ability resolves. If you control no artifacts at that time, you must sacrifice Glint Hawk. Although players can respond to the ability, once it starts to resolve and you choose an artifact you control to return to its owner's hand, it's too late for players to respond.

cards.originalText:
Flying
When Glint Hawk enters the battlefield, sacrifice it unless you return an artifact you control to its owner's hand.

cards.name: Indomitable Archangel
cards.text:
Flying
Metalcraft — Artifacts you control have shroud as long as you control three or more artifacts. (An artifact with shroud can't be the target of spells or abilities.)
cards.flavor:
"Every sword drawn to defend is an angelic blade, guided to justice by an angelic hand."
—Auriok proverb
cards.originalText:
Flying
Metalcraft — Artifacts you control have shroud as long as you control three or more artifacts.

cards.name: Kemba, Kha Regent
cards.text: At the beginning of your upkeep, create a 2/2 white Cat creature token for each Equipment attached to Kemba, Kha Regent.
cards.flavor: "I am not Raksha. I never will be. But I refuse to be the kha who watched her pride be torn asunder."

rulings.text: The number of Equipment attached to Kemba is determined as the ability resolves. If Kemba is no longer on the battlefield at that time, its last existence on the battlefield is checked to determine the number of Equipment attached to it.

cards.originalText: At the beginning of your upkeep, put a 2/2 white Cat creature token onto the battlefield for each Equipment attached to Kemba, Kha Regent.

cards.name: Kemba's Skyguard
cards.text:
Flying
When Kemba's Skyguard enters the battlefield, you gain 2 life.
cards.flavor:
"We're now to dispense aid to any Mirran we see battling anything . . . 'strange.' Regent's orders."
—Ranya, skyhunter captain
cards.originalText:
Flying
When Kemba's Skyguard enters the battlefield, you gain 2 life.

cards.name: Leonin Arbiter
cards.text: Players can't search libraries. Any player may pay {2} for that player to ignore this effect until end of turn.
cards.flavor: "Our people are torn by infighting. Until the two sides reconcile, our laws can carry no meaning."

rulings.text: If an effect says "You may search your library . . . If you do, shuffle your library," and you haven't paid {2}, you can't choose to search, so you won't shuffle.
If an effect says "Search your library . . . Then shuffle your library," and you haven't paid {2}, the search effect fails, but you will still have to shuffle.

Since players who haven't paid {2} can't search, they won't be able to find any cards in a library. The effect applies to all players and all libraries. If a spell or ability's effect has other parts that don't depend on searching for or finding cards, they will still work normally.
Effects that tell a player to reveal cards from a library or look at cards from the top of a library will still work. Only effects that use the word "search" will fail unless a player pays {2}.
Paying {2} to ignore Leonin Arbiter's effect is a special action. Any player may take this special action any time they have priority. It doesn't use the stack and can't be responded to.

Paying {2} doesn't let a player pick up a library and search it — it just allows them to ignore Leonin Arbiter's effect that turn. That player can search a library only if another spell or ability instructs them to do so.
If a player pays {2}, that enables only them to ignore Leonin Arbiter's effect that turn. Each other player is still affected by it.
A player who has paid {2} may search any library when instructed to do so that turn, not just their own library.
Once a player has paid {2}, they may search libraries that turn as many times as they are instructed to do so.
If there are multiple Leonin Arbiters on the battlefield, a player must pay {2} for each one before being able to search libraries that turn.

cards.originalText: Players can't search libraries. Any player may pay {2} for that player to ignore this effect until end of turn.

cards.name: Loxodon Wayfarer
cards.flavor: The Mirran elders vanished with Memnarch, leaving behind a generation of wayward orphans.

cards.name: Myrsmith
cards.text: Whenever you cast an artifact spell, you may pay {1}. If you do, create a 1/1 colorless Myr artifact creature token.
cards.flavor: The Auriok see the artificer as a conduit, beckoning new creations into the world.
cards.originalText: Whenever you cast an artifact spell, you may pay {1}. If you do, put a 1/1 colorless Myr artifact creature token onto the battlefield.

cards.name: Razor Hippogriff
cards.text:
Flying
When Razor Hippogriff enters the battlefield, return target artifact card from your graveyard to your hand. You gain life equal to that card's converted mana cost.
cards.flavor: She incubates her eggs in gold and mana.

rulings.text: If the artifact card in your graveyard is an illegal target by the time the ability resolves, the ability won't resolve. You won't gain any life.
If the mana cost of the targeted card includes {X}, X is considered to be 0.

cards.originalText:
Flying
When Razor Hippogriff enters the battlefield, return target artifact card from your graveyard to your hand. You gain life equal to that card's converted mana cost.

cards.name: Revoke Existence
cards.text: Exile target artifact or enchantment.
cards.flavor:
"No half measures, no regrets. We'll tell no stories of this day. It will be as if it never existed at all."
—Ganedor, loxodon mystic
cards.originalText: Exile target artifact or enchantment.

cards.name: Salvage Scout
cards.text: {W}, Sacrifice Salvage Scout: Return target artifact card from your graveyard to your hand.
cards.flavor: "I'm not saying it's dangerous work. I'm just saying don't sign up if you have plans for your seventieth birthday."
cards.originalText: {W}, Sacrifice Salvage Scout: Return target artifact card from your graveyard to your hand.

cards.name: Seize the Initiative
cards.text: Target creature gets +1/+1 and gains first strike until end of turn.
cards.flavor: The time between spotting a leonin shikari and feeling its claws is just time enough to draw your last breath.

rulings.text: A creature that gains first strike after other creatures with first strike or double strike deal combat damage in the first combat damage step will still deal damage in the second combat damage step.

cards.originalText: Target creature gets +1/+1 and gains first strike until end of turn.

cards.name: Soul Parry
cards.text: Prevent all damage one or two target creatures would deal this turn.
cards.flavor:
"I was called to this world of steel, and it will be my steel that answers."
—Elspeth Tirel

rulings.text: Soul Parry prevents all damage the targeted creatures would deal this turn, not just combat damage.

cards.originalText: Prevent all damage one or two target creatures would deal this turn.

cards.name: Sunblast Angel
cards.text:
Flying
When Sunblast Angel enters the battlefield, destroy all tapped creatures.
cards.flavor: There may exist powers even greater than Phyrexia.

rulings.text: The second ability destroys each creature that's tapped at the time it resolves, including creatures you control. If Sunblast Angel has become tapped by the time its ability resolves, it will be destroyed too.

cards.originalText:
Flying
When Sunblast Angel enters the battlefield, destroy all tapped creatures.

cards.name: Sunspear Shikari
cards.text: As long as Sunspear Shikari is equipped, it has first strike and lifelink.
cards.flavor: Left without their leader Raksha, the leonin split into two prides: one side supported the regent kha, while the other rebelled in fury.

rulings.text: If all Equipment attached to Sunspear Shikari somehow becomes unequipped after it deals combat damage in the first combat damage step, it won't assign combat damage in the second combat damage step.

cards.originalText: As long as Sunspear Shikari is equipped, it has first strike and lifelink.

cards.name: Tempered Steel
cards.text: Artifact creatures you control get +2/+2.
cards.flavor:
"Death shall prevail as long as our will falls to rust. May necessity anneal our resolve."
—Ghalma the Shaper
cards.originalText: Artifact creatures you control get +2/+2.

cards.name: True Conviction
cards.text: Creatures you control have double strike and lifelink.
cards.flavor: Dozens of spells known only to the Auriok elders were lost, but the next generation, galvanized by war, devised even more potent magic.
cards.originalText: Creatures you control have double strike and lifelink.

cards.name: Vigil for the Lost
cards.text: Whenever a creature you control dies, you may pay {X}. If you do, you gain X life.
cards.flavor: "As she grew cold in my arms, I swore an oath that her funeral pyre would be dwarfed by a bonfire of our enemies."

rulings.text: As the ability resolves, you choose a value for X and decide whether to pay {X}. If you do decide to pay {X}, it's too late for any player to respond since the ability is already in the midst of resolving.

cards.originalText: Whenever a creature you control is put into a graveyard from the battlefield, you may pay {X}. If you do, you gain X life.

cards.name: Whitesun's Passage
cards.text: You gain 5 life.
cards.flavor: All over the Razor Fields, Whitesun is celebrated. Even the followers of the rebel Juryan, far from the Cave of Light, bow their heads in reverence.
cards.originalText: You gain 5 life.

cards.name: Argent Sphinx
cards.text:
Flying
Metalcraft — {U}: Exile Argent Sphinx. Return it to the battlefield under your control at the beginning of the next end step. Activate this ability only if you control three or more artifacts.
cards.flavor: A great mirage, a dream of wings and silver.

rulings.text: If you activate Argent Sphinx's metalcraft ability, Argent Sphinx will return to the battlefield at the beginning of the next end step no matter how many artifacts you control at that time.
If you activate Argent Sphinx's metalcraft ability during a turn's end step, Argent Sphinx will return to the battlefield at the beginning of the following turn's end step.

If you control an Argent Sphinx owned by another player and activate its ability, Argent Sphinx will return to the battlefield under your control at the beginning of the next end step. You'll retain control of it indefinitely.

cards.originalText:
Flying
Metalcraft — {U}: Exile Argent Sphinx. Return it to the battlefield under your control at the beginning of the next end step. Activate this ability only if you control three or more artifacts.

cards.name: Bonds of Quicksilver
cards.text:
Flash (You may cast this spell any time you could cast an instant.)
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature doesn't untap during its controller's untap step.
cards.flavor: The sea's reach extends beyond its shores.

rulings.text: Bonds of Quicksilver may target and may enchant an untapped creature.

cards.originalText:
Flash (You may cast this spell any time you could cast an instant.)
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature doesn't untap during its controller's untap step.

cards.name: Darkslick Drake
cards.text:
Flying
When Darkslick Drake dies, draw a card.
cards.flavor: At the edge of the Mephidross, Phyrexia's influence seeps into life and land.
cards.originalText:
Flying
When Darkslick Drake is put into a graveyard from the battlefield, draw a card.

cards.name: Disperse
cards.text: Return target nonland permanent to its owner's hand.
cards.flavor: Most casualties of the power struggle between vedalken and Neurok didn't die on the field of battle; they merely disappeared.
cards.originalText: Return target nonland permanent to its owner's hand.

cards.name: Dissipation Field
cards.text: Whenever a permanent deals damage to you, return it to its owner's hand.
cards.flavor:
"Strike me once, shame on you. Strike me twice . . . Well, let's just see if you can."
—Kara Vrist, Neurok agent

rulings.text: The ability triggers whenever you're dealt any damage (not just combat damage) by any permanent (not just creatures). This includes permanents you control.

cards.originalText: Whenever a permanent deals damage to you, return it to its owner's hand.

cards.name: Grand Architect
cards.text:
Other blue creatures you control get +1/+1.
{U}: Target artifact creature becomes blue until end of turn.
Tap an untapped blue creature you control: Add {C}{C}. Spend this mana only to cast artifact spells or activate abilities of artifacts.

rulings.text: Other blue creatures you control will get +1/+1 whether they are artifacts or not.

Turning an artifact creature blue with the second ability will override any other color(s) the creature previously had. It will still be an artifact. You may target a blue artifact creature with this ability.

Since Grand Architect's last ability doesn't have a tap symbol in its cost, you can tap a blue creature (including Grand Architect itself) that hasn't been under your control since your most recent turn began to pay the cost.

cards.originalText:
Other blue creatures you control get +1/+1.
{U}: Target artifact creature becomes blue until end of turn.
Tap an untapped blue creature you control: Add {2} to your mana pool. Spend this mana only to cast artifact spells or activate abilities of artifacts.

cards.name: Halt Order
cards.text:
Counter target artifact spell.
Draw a card.
cards.flavor: An artificer's least favorite mind-missive may be "I regret to inform you that the funding for your project has been cut."
cards.originalText:
Counter target artifact spell.
Draw a card.

cards.name: Inexorable Tide
cards.text: Whenever you cast a spell, proliferate. (You choose any number of permanents and/or players with counters on them, then give each another counter of a kind already there.)
cards.flavor:
"See how gratefully this world accepts our blessings."
—Jin-Gitaxias, Core Augur

rulings.text: You can choose any player that has a counter, including yourself.

You can choose any permanent that has a counter, including ones controlled by opponents. You can't choose cards in any zone other than the battlefield, even if they have counters on them, such as suspended cards or a Lightning Storm on the stack.

You don't have to choose every permanent or player that has a counter, only the ones you want to add another counter to. Since "any number" includes zero, you don't have to choose any permanents at all, and you don't have to choose any players at all.
If a permanent chosen this way has multiple kinds of counters on it, only a single new counter is put on that permanent.

Players can respond to the spell or ability whose effect includes proliferating. Once that spell or ability starts to resolve, however, and its controller chooses which permanents and players will get new counters, it's too late for anyone to respond.
Whenever you cast a spell, Inexorable Tide's ability triggers and goes on the stack on top of it. It will resolve (and you'll proliferate) before the spell resolves.

cards.originalText: Whenever you cast a spell, proliferate. (You choose any number of permanents and/or players with counters on them, then give each another counter of a kind already there.)

cards.name: Lumengrid Drake
cards.text:
Flying
Metalcraft — When Lumengrid Drake enters the battlefield, if you control three or more artifacts, return target creature to its owner's hand.
cards.flavor: Properly outfitted, drakes made perfect sentries for vedalken strongholds.

rulings.text: The triggered ability is mandatory. If you control three or more artifacts as Lumengrid Drake enters the battlefield, you must target a creature. If there are no other creatures on the battlefield, you must target Lumengrid Drake itself. As the ability resolves, if you control three or more artifacts, you must return the targeted creature to its owner's hand.

foreignNames.name: ルーメングリッドのドレイク

cards.originalText:
Flying
Metalcraft — When Lumengrid Drake enters the battlefield, if you control three or more artifacts, return target creature to its owner's hand.

cards.name: Neurok Invisimancer
cards.text:
Neurok Invisimancer can't be blocked.
When Neurok Invisimancer enters the battlefield, target creature can't be blocked this turn.
cards.flavor: "They won't see your shadow or hear your breath, but they will feel your blade."

foreignNames.name: ニューロックの透術士

cards.originalText:
Neurok Invisimancer is unblockable.
When Neurok Invisimancer enters the battlefield, target creature is unblockable this turn.

cards.name: Plated Seastrider
cards.flavor: The Neurok buried entangling cables just under the Quicksilver Sea. One seastrider harvest can provide an army's worth of armor and shields.

cards.name: Quicksilver Gargantuan
cards.text: You may have Quicksilver Gargantuan enter the battlefield as a copy of any creature on the battlefield, except it's 7/7.
cards.flavor:
"You know you have achieved true power if the sea itself seeks to emulate your greatness."
—Vy Covalt, Neurok agent

rulings.text: Except for its power and toughness, Quicksilver Gargantuan copies exactly what was printed on the original creature and nothing more (unless that creature is copying something else or is a token; see below). It doesn't copy whether that creature is tapped or untapped, whether it has any counters on it or Auras attached to it, or any non-copy effects that have changed its power, toughness, types, color, or so on.
If the chosen creature has {X} in its mana cost (such as Protean Hydra), X is considered to be zero.

If the chosen creature is copying something else (for example, if the chosen creature is a Clone), then your Quicksilver Gargantuan enters the battlefield as whatever the chosen creature copied, except for its power and toughness.

If the chosen creature is a token, your Quicksilver Gargantuan copies the original characteristics of that token as stated by the effect that put the token onto the battlefield, except for its power and toughness. Your Quicksilver Gargantuan is not a token.

If Quicksilver Gargantuan is not a creature (for example, if it entered the battlefield as a copy of an animated land), it will not have the characteristics of power or toughness at all, so it won't be 7/7. If it later becomes a creature, its power and toughness will be determined by the effect that causes it to become a creature; again, it won't be 7/7.

Any enters-the-battlefield abilities of the copied creature will trigger when Quicksilver Gargantuan enters the battlefield. Any "as [this creature] enters the battlefield" or "[this creature] enters the battlefield with" abilities of the chosen creature will also work.

If Quicksilver Gargantuan somehow enters the battlefield at the same time as another creature (due to Mass Polymorph or Liliana Vess's third ability, for example), Quicksilver Gargantuan can't become a copy of that creature. You may choose only a creature that's already on the battlefield.
You can choose not to copy anything. In that case, Quicksilver Gargantuan simply enters the battlefield as a 7/7 creature.

If the chosen creature has a characteristic-defining ability that sets its power and/or toughness, that ability will not be copied. For example, if Quicksilver Gargantuan copies a Nightmare, it will not gain the ability that sets its power and toughness to the number of Swamps you control. As such, it will remain a 7/7.

foreignNames.name: 水銀のガルガンチュアン

cards.originalText: You may have Quicksilver Gargantuan enter the battlefield as a copy of any creature on the battlefield, except it's still 7/7.

cards.name: Riddlesmith
cards.text: Whenever you cast an artifact spell, you may draw a card. If you do, discard a card.
cards.flavor: The Neurok see the artificer as an archaeologist, clearing away falsehoods to see the truth hidden beneath.
cards.originalText: Whenever you cast an artifact spell, you may draw a card. If you do, discard a card.

cards.name: Scrapdiver Serpent
cards.text: Scrapdiver Serpent can't be blocked as long as defending player controls an artifact.
cards.flavor: Smart artificers clean up after themselves.

rulings.text: Whether Scrapdiver Serpent can be blocked is relevant only as the declare blockers step begins. If the defending player gains control of an artifact after Scrapdiver Serpent has become blocked, the Serpent will remain blocked.

cards.originalText: Scrapdiver Serpent is unblockable as long as defending player controls an artifact.

cards.name: Screeching Silcaw
cards.text:
Flying
Metalcraft — Whenever Screeching Silcaw deals combat damage to a player, if you control three or more artifacts, that player puts the top four cards of their library into their graveyard.
cards.flavor: It's adaptively deaf to its own cries.
cards.originalText:
Flying
Metalcraft — Whenever Screeching Silcaw deals combat damage to a player, if you control three or more artifacts, that player puts the top four cards of his or her library into his or her graveyard.

cards.name: Shape Anew
cards.text: The controller of target artifact sacrifices it, then reveals cards from the top of their library until they reveal an artifact card. That player puts that card onto the battlefield, then shuffles all other cards revealed this way into their library.

rulings.text: If the targeted artifact is an illegal target by the time Shape Anew resolves, the spell doesn't resolve. Nothing else happens.
If the first card the player reveals is an artifact card, they will still have to shuffle their library even though no other cards were revealed this way.
If there are no artifact cards in the player's library, all the cards in that library are revealed, then the library is shuffled. (The targeted artifact remains sacrificed.)
If the targeted artifact's controller can't sacrifice it (due to Tajuru Preserver, perhaps), the other effects of the spell will still happen.

cards.originalText: The controller of target artifact sacrifices it, then reveals cards from the top of his or her library until he or she reveals an artifact card. That player puts that card onto the battlefield, then shuffles all other cards revealed this way into his or her library.

cards.name: Sky-Eel School
cards.text:
Flying
When Sky-Eel School enters the battlefield, draw a card, then discard a card.
cards.flavor: They swim on tides few can see, away from a threat few yet understand.
cards.originalText:
Flying
When Sky-Eel School enters the battlefield, draw a card, then discard a card.

cards.name: Steady Progress
cards.text:
Proliferate. (You choose any number of permanents and/or players with counters on them, then give each another counter of a kind already there.)
Draw a card.
cards.flavor: "More of that strange oil . . . It's probably nothing."

rulings.text: You can choose any player that has a counter, including yourself.

You can choose any permanent that has a counter, including ones controlled by opponents. You can't choose cards in any zone other than the battlefield, even if they have counters on them, such as suspended cards or a Lightning Storm on the stack.

You don't have to choose every permanent or player that has a counter, only the ones you want to add another counter to. Since "any number" includes zero, you don't have to choose any permanents at all, and you don't have to choose any players at all.
If a permanent chosen this way has multiple kinds of counters on it, only a single new counter is put on that permanent.

Players can respond to the spell or ability whose effect includes proliferating. Once that spell or ability starts to resolve, however, and its controller chooses which permanents and players will get new counters, it's too late for anyone to respond.
This spell has no targets. You can cast it even if there are no players or permanents with counters on them. If you do, you'll simply draw a card as it resolves.

cards.originalText:
Proliferate. (You choose any number of permanents and/or players with counters on them, then give each another counter of a kind already there.)
Draw a card.

cards.name: Stoic Rebuttal
cards.text:
Metalcraft — This spell costs {1} less to cast if you control three or more artifacts.
Counter target spell.
cards.flavor: Obsessed with the pursuit of knowledge above all else, vedalken can appear to be cold and emotionless.

rulings.text: Stoic Rebuttal's metalcraft ability functions while Stoic Rebuttal is on the stack.

For the purpose of determining whether the cost reduction applies, the number of artifacts you control is checked as you cast Stoic Rebuttal, before your last chance to activate mana abilities to pay for it. For example, if you control three artifacts, you could determine that Stoic Rebuttal costs {U}{U} to cast, then sacrifice one of those artifacts to activate a mana ability.

cards.originalText:
Metalcraft — Stoic Rebuttal costs {1} less to cast if you control three or more artifacts.
Counter target spell.
